paper.title: Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b

core_question: Does TRAPPIST-1 b retain an atmosphere under strong stellar irradiation from its M dwarf host star, and what are the constraints on its atmospheric composition and thermal properties?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: TRAPPIST-1 b JWST MIRI observation
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: Phase-resolved thermal spectra across full orbital cycle
datasets_or_cohorts.description: JWST MIRI low-resolution spectroscopy measuring thermal emission from TRAPPIST-1 b throughout its orbit, capturing both day-side and night-side thermal emission variations.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: No-atmosphere bare-rock scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Theoretical model representing an airless rocky planet with minimal heat redistribution between day and night sides.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: CO2-rich atmosphere retrieval family
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Atmosphere model incorporating greenhouse gas absorption, particularly targeting the 15 um CO2 spectral band signature.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: O2-rich atmosphere retrieval family
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Alternative oxidized atmospheric composition scenario with weaker CO2 signature constraints for comparison.

major_limitations: Single-planet study does not establish atmospheric prevalence across M-dwarf rocky planets generally
Retrieval assumptions including circulation patterns, opacity priors, and cloud treatment affect quantitative posteriors
Stellar variability and instrument systematics can potentially bias weak spectral feature detection
Night-side thermal constraints are weaker than day-side constraints in the current dataset
Degeneracies between atmospheric composition, cloud/haze properties, and circulation assumptions remain significant
